translation.title: In the Form of an Elephant King

segments.en: 2. In the Form of an Elephant King

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
segments.en: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the root of the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattandhakāratimisāyaṃ abbhokāse nisinno hoti, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyati.
segments.en: Now at that time the Buddha was meditating in the open during the dark of night, while a gentle rain drizzled down.

segments.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā bhagavato bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo mahantaṃ hatthirājavaṇṇaṃ abhinimminitvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the Buddha feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, manifested in the form of a huge elephant king and approached him.
Its head was like a huge block of soapstone.
Its tusks were like pure silver.
Its trunk was like a long plough pole.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, addressed him in verse:
you’ve made forms beautiful and ugly.

segments.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
segments.en: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

suttaplex.blurb: Māra manifests before the Buddha in the form of a ferocious elephant in order to scare him.
